org.apache.cassandra.io.compress

Class BufferRecycler

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.cassandra.io.compress.BufferRecycler

  • public final class BufferRecycler
extends java.lang.Object
    BufferRecycler allows for fast and GC-friendly allocation of data buffers used e.g. by compression. When the client is done with the buffer, instead of dropping a reference to it and letting it be collected by GC, it can call the recycle method in order to save it for the future use. This class takes care of eventually releasing reference to the recycled buffer later, if it is not used for some time. A recycled buffer can be reused by a different thread than the thread that created it. BufferRecycler shouldn't be used for very small buffers (e.g. < 1kB), because it incurs some CPU overhead per each allocation which is probably bigger than calling ByteBuffer.allocateDirect.

    • Method Detail

      • allocate

        public java.nio.ByteBuffer allocate(int minCapacity)
        Allocates an on-heap byte buffer. Buffer may be either brand new or refurbished. Buffers are first searched in the thread local buffer pool, then in the pools of other threads. This method is thread-safe.
        Parameters:
        minCapacity - minimum capacity of the buffer
        Returns:
        an on-heap buffer; @see ByteBuffer.allocate

      • allocateDirect

        public java.nio.ByteBuffer allocateDirect(int minCapacity)
        Allocates a direct byte buffer. Buffer may be either brand new or refurbished. Buffers are first searched in the thread local buffer pool, then in the pools of other threads. This method is thread-safe.
        Parameters:
        minCapacity - minimum capacity of the buffer
        Returns:
        a direct buffer, @see ByteBuffer.allocateDirect

      • recycle

        public void recycle(java.nio.ByteBuffer buffer)
        Returns the buffer to the pool so it can be reused later by this thread or some other threads. This method is thread-safe. Recycling a null buffer is a no-op.
        Parameters:
        buffer - buffer to be recycled

      • recycle

        public void recycle(java.nio.ByteBuffer buffer,
           int ttl)
        Returns the buffer to the pool so it can be reused later by this thread or some other threads. This method is thread-safe. Recycling a null buffer is a no-op.
        Parameters:
        buffer - buffer to be recycled
        ttl - time to live in milliseconds; after this time the buffer may be handed over to another thread or removed completely

      • shutdown

        public void shutdown()
        Terminates the background buffer expiring thread
